meanings.definition: The appearance of being true or real.
meanings.sent1: The movie's verisimilitude made it feel like I was actually there.
meanings.sent2: The novel lacked verisimilitude, making it hard to believe in the story.
meanings.sent3: The play's verisimilitude was so convincing, I almost thought the actors were real people.
meanings.sent4: Her painting achieved a level of verisimilitude that captured the essence of the landscape.
meanings.sent5: The artist's attention to detail created a sense of verisimilitude that drew viewers in.

meanings.definition: The quality of seeming true or real.
meanings.sent1: The verisimilitude of the special effects in the movie was impressive.
meanings.sent2: The verisimilitude of the actor's performance brought the character to life.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick had such verisimilitude that the audience gasped in amazement.
meanings.sent4: The verisimilitude of her excuse was so convincing that no one questioned her absence.
meanings.sent5: The verisimilitude of the historical reenactment made it feel like stepping back in time.

meanings.definition: The likelihood of something being true or real.
meanings.sent1: There is a high verisimilitude that the sun will rise tomorrow.
meanings.sent2: The verisimilitude of his alibi was questionable.
meanings.sent3: The verisimilitude of winning the lottery is very low.
meanings.sent4: The verisimilitude of her story being true seemed doubtful.
meanings.sent5: The verisimilitude of the theory being correct was debated among scientists.
